p: Although inflammation is a beneficial response that helps to protect the body from external pathogens, it is considered that excessive inflammatory responses should be controlled to prevent the development of chronic inflammation-associated diseases ( 1, 2). The development of new anti-inflammatory agents is desirable due to the side effects and treatment failures associated with currently available anti-inflammatory drugs ( 35). There is growing evidence that various plants and plant-derived compounds have therapeutic anti-inflammatory effects with few or no side effects ( 35, 36). Thus, in the present study, the anti-inflammatory activity of HBL and HBB derived from honeyberry were evaluated and their potential molecular mechanisms of action were elucidated.
